description: From Middle English butler, butlere, boteler, botelere, from Old French buttiler, butiller, boteillier (“officer in charge of wine”), from Medieval Latin botellārius, equivalent to bottle +‎ -er.

entries.meaning: A manservant having charge of wines and liquors.
The chief male servant of a household who has charge of other employees, receives guests, directs the serving of meals, and performs various personal services.
A valet, a male personal attendant.

verbs.description: butler (third-person singular simple present butlers, present participle butlering, simple past and past participle butlered)

entries.meaning: To buttle, to dispense wines or liquors; to take the place of a butler.
